map_node.indicator_name: Home fall-related hospitalizations among older adults

dataset.how_calculated: Age-adjusted rates were calculated per 100,000 population 65 years and older weighted to the 2016 NYC DOHMH population estimates using the following age groups for weighting: 65-74, 75-84, and 85+ years old. Numerator consists of NYC hospitalizations related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older, identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. Hospitalizations for a fall that occurred at home were identified using place of injury ICD10 code Y920 and then limited to the following building classes: "Condominiums," "Elevator Apartments," "One-family Dwellings," "Two-family Dwellings," "Walk-up Apartments," "Residence Multiple Use." Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
dataset.discription: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) emergency department data, 2016, updated January 2018. ,NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2016. Updated September 2017.
dataset.legend_title: Age-Adjusted Rate (per 100,000 population 65 yrs and older)

show_disparities_node.disparitiesPagetext: When population health or the quality of living environments varies by population characteristics such as income or race, there is disparity. One way to visualize disparity is to chart indicators of health or environment across levels of neighborhood poverty. We categorized neighborhoods as high, medium or low poverty. Then we took the median of the neighborhood-specific values in each category. The median is the middle of the sorted group of values.
show_disparities_node.indicator_name: Home fall-related hospitalizations among older adults

Link.graph_title: Home fall-related hospitalizations among older adults
Link.y_axis_title: Age-Adjusted Rate (per 100,000 population 65 yrs and older) (Median of Neighborhoods)

info.info_name: Home fall-related hospitalizations among older adults
info.info_how_calculated: Age-adjusted rates were calculated per 100,000 population 65 years and older weighted to the 2016 NYC DOHMH population estimates using the following age groups for weighting: 65-74, 75-84, and 85+ years old. Numerator consists of NYC hospitalizations related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older, identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. Hospitalizations for a fall that occurred at home were identified using place of injury ICD10 code Y920 and then limited to the following building classes: "Condominiums," "Elevator Apartments," "One-family Dwellings," "Two-family Dwellings," "Walk-up Apartments," "Residence Multiple Use." Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) emergency department data, 2016, updated January 2018. ,NYC DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau interpolated intercensal population estimates, 2016. Updated September 2017.

info.info_how_calculated: Neighborhoods are ranked according to the percent of people whose annual income falls below 100% of the federal poverty level. Rankings are then divided into 3 approximately equal groupings of low, medium and high poverty.

info.info_name: Home fall-related hospitalizations among older adults
info.info_how_calculated: Number of NYC hospitalizations related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. Hospitalizations for a fall that occurred at home were identified using place of injury ICD10 code Y920 and then limited to the following building classes: "Condominiums," "Elevator Apartments," "One-family Dwellings," "Two-family Dwellings," "Walk-up Apartments," "Residence Multiple Use." Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) emergency department data, 2016, updated January 2018.

Hospitalizations for a fall that occurred at home were identified using place of injury ICD10 code Y920 and then limited to the following building classes: "Condominiums," "Elevator Apartments," "One-family Dwellings," "Two-family Dwellings," "Walk-up Apartments," "Residence Multiple Use." Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.
